event_registry_properties.name: action
event_registry_properties.item: Schedule a repair procedure to replace the affected CPU. Use 'fmadm faulty' to identify the module.
event_registry_properties.name: description
event_registry_properties.item: A level 2 Instruction Cache on this cpu is faulty.
event_registry_properties.name: details
event_registry_properties.item:
This message ID: GMCA-8000-RG indicates that the %DISTRO% Fault Manager has received reports from a CPU indicating that one or more errors have occurred with this resource resulting in a CPU fault being diagnosed. If an uncorrectable error was reported, it likely resulted in a system panic or reset followed by a reboot. If the errors were correctable, they have occurred at a rate exceeding acceptable levels. There should have been no operational impact on system or application activity from correctable errors.

The recommended service action for this event is to schedule replacement of the affected CPU at the earliest possible convenience. The faulted CPU has been off-lined to prevent further disruption to system availability. However it is not intended nor recommended that the faulted FRU remain in the system for a prolonged period of time.

Identifying the fauty FRU varies depending on the type of Hardware.

Follow the procedure below that applies to your system.

    A) Identify FRU on Sun x64 systems -

    B) Identify FRU on third party systems -

A) Identify FRU on Sun x64 systems, Follow the steps below to complete FRU identification.

Step 1: Use fmadm (1M) faulty to List Faulty FRUs, identify unique Event_ID string, and Sun Message_ID.
See Example 1.1 for details.

LEGEND:
GREEN = FRU
BLUE = EVENT_ID
RED = SUNW-MSG-ID

    Example 1.1 - finding faulty FRU, Event_ID, and Sun Message_ID 
    
# fmadm faulty
--------------- ------------------------------------  -------------- ---------
TIME            EVENT-ID                              MSG-ID         SEVERITY
--------------- ------------------------------------  -------------- ---------
Sep 22 14:34:31 697735d4-dab0-cf5e-cc94-805bde46e5e0  GMAC-8000-RG    Major

Fault class : fault.cpu.generic-x86.l2icache

Affects     : cpu:///cpuid=0

FRU         : "CPU 0" (hc://:product-id=Sun-Fire-X4100-Server:chassis-id=0618AM0781:
              server-id=backmarker/motherboard=0/chip=0) faulty
  

Description : The number of errors associated with this CPU has exceeded
              acceptable levels.  Refer to %FMAURL%/GMAC-8000-RG for
              more information.

Response    : An attempt will be made to remove this CPU from service.

Impact      : Performance of this system may be affected.

Action      : Schedule a repair procedure to replace the affected CPU.  Use
              fmdump -v -u  to identify the module.

If a FRU label is supplied like ("CPU 0" as seen above) go to Procedure C) Completing the recommended repair action

Note:If no FRU label ("CPU 0" as seen above) is listed then you'll need to follow procedure B (Step 1) listed below.

B) Identify FRU on third party systems, Follow the steps below to complete FRU identification

Step 1: Use fmadm (1M) faulty to List Faulty FRUs, identify unique Event_ID string, and Sun Message_ID.
See Example 1.1 for details.

LEGEND:
GREEN = FRU
BLUE = EVENT_ID
RED = SUNW-MSG-ID

    Example 1.1 - finding faulty FRU, Event_ID, and Message_ID

    On non-Sun systems there will be no FRU label or serial information in fmadm faulty output. We must identify the FRU for replacement based on the resource identifier in fmamd faulty output: 

    
# fmadm faulty
--------------- ------------------------------------  -------------- ---------
TIME            EVENT-ID                              MSG-ID         SEVERITY
--------------- ------------------------------------  -------------- ---------
Sep 22 14:34:31 697735d4-dab0-cf5e-cc94-805bde46e5e0  GMAC-8000-RG    Major

Fault class : fault.cpu.generic-x86.l2icache

Affects     : cpu:///cpuid=0

FRU         :  hc://:product-id=ThirdParty:server-id=random/
               motherboard=0/chip=0 faulty
  

Description : The number of errors associated with this CPU has exceeded
              acceptable levels.  Refer to %FMAURL%/GMAC-8000-RG for
              more information.

Response    : An attempt will be made to remove this CPU from service.

Impact      : Performance of this system may be affected.

Action      : Schedule a repair procedure to replace the affected CPU.  Use
              fmdump -v -u  to identify the module.

As seen in Example 1.1 The FRU is identified as motherboard=0/chip=0.

The term 'chip' used in the output above can also be used to refer to a processor or CPU chip, hence 'chip=x' equates to 'CPU chipx'. Note that the cpuid refers to a logical CPU number within the CPU chip.

chip=x maps to the processor chip labeled within the system.
The CPU socket for chip=x will usually have a physical label of CPU#, CHIP#, P#...

For example:

    chip=0 maps to the physical location labeled; CPU0, CHIP0, P0...
    chip=1 maps to the physical location labeled; CPU1, CHIP1, P1...

    In this example replace chip labeled CPU0, CHIP0, P0...

Proceed with Procedure C Completing the recommended repair action

C) Completing the recommended repair action

Step 1: Replace chip labeled CPU0, CHIP0, P0...(and reboot the system)

    Refer to the service label or hardware maintenance manual for correct replacement procedures.

Step 2: Update the Fault Manager's resource cache to indicate that no problems are present in the resources that had been diagnosed faulty and subsequently replaced in Step 1.

Once the CPU has been physically replaced and the system rebooted, you must invoke the 'fmadm repair' command using the UUID (Universally Unique IDentifier) to identify the repaired FRU. The UUID is synonymous with the EVENT_ID (highlighted in blue) in procedures A or B Example 1.1 above.

    Example 2.1 - Updating the Fault Manager's resource cache: 
    # fmadm repair 697735d4-dab0-cf5e-cc94-805bde46e5e0
# fmadm: recorded repair to 697735d4-dab0-cf5e-cc94-805bde46e5e0

Step 3: Bring the faulted resource back online by placing the CPU back into the active configuration.

Once you have completed the repair action, and told the fault manager that the FRU has been repaired, it may still be necessary to tell %DISTRO% to use the affected system resource. If the Automated Response described above in this article was; "An attempt will be made to remove this CPU from service.", you will need to place the CPU back into the active configuration and verify that the CPU has been returned to service.

Use %DISTRO% command psrinfo (1M) to identify the logical CPU number that was faulted. Example 3.1 below.

    Example 3.1 - identifying the logical CPU number that was faulted: 
    # psrinfo
0       faulted   since 09/22/2008 14:34:31
1       on-line   since 09/22/2008 14:31:30
2       on-line   since 09/22/2008 14:34:32
3       on-line   since 09/22/2008 14:34:34

Place the faulted CPU back into the active configuration using the psradm (1M) command; 'psradm -F -n x' where x is the logical cpuid. As logical CPU 0 was identified as the faulted CPU, the psradm (1M) command shown in Example 3.2 below will return it to the active configuration.

    Example 3.2 - returning the repaired CPU to the active configuration: 
    # psradm -F -n 0

Step 4: Verify the CPU is in use by the system.

To verify that the CPU has been returned to service, use the %DISTRO% command psrinfo (1M). See Example 4.1 below.

    Example 4.1 - verifying the CPU has returned to service: 
    # psrinfo
0       on-line   since 09/22/2008 14:45:16
1       on-line   since 09/22/2008 14:44:19
2       on-line   since 09/22/2008 14:44:57
3       on-line   since 09/22/2008 14:44:23
event_registry_properties.name: impact
event_registry_properties.item: Performance of this system may be affected.
event_registry_properties.name: response
event_registry_properties.item: The system will attempt to offline this cpu to remove it from service.
event_registry_properties.name: title
